Jowett, p. 38 |march= |mascot= |battles= [[World War II]] |anniversaries= |decorations= |battle_honours= }} The '''53rd Infantry Division Arezzo''' was a regular [[infantry]] [[Division (military)|division]] of the [[Royal Italian Army (1940–1946)|Italian Army]] during [[World War II]]. It was formed 24 May 1939 and officially dissolved 12 September 1943.http://www.regioesercito.it/reparti/fanteria/rgt/rgt226.htm The ''Arezzo'' division is not related to partisan division "Arezzo" ({{IPA-it|aˈrɛttso}} {{audio|It-Arezzo.ogg|listen}}) operating in 1943 in the [[Cortona]] vicinity under command of Siro Rossetti.The Arezzo Massacres A TuscanTragedy By Janet Kinrade Dethick, p. 14 ==Action== The ''Arezzo'' Division took part in the [[Italian invasion of Albania]] in 1939. It was next involved in the [[Greco-Italian War]] in November 1940, as part of the [[Italian XXVI Corps]] and later [[Italian XXV Corps]]. Although it was used initially on Yugoslavian border as part of the 11th army reserve, the division used to oppose a Greek beakthrough at Mal Moravë - Mal Ivan line in [[Devoll (river)|Devoll]] river valley. The ''Arezzo'' losses were light until December, 1940.The Defence and Fall of Greece 1940-1941 By John Carr, p. 116 29 November-3 December 1940 division have suffered a serious losses (the 225th Infantry regiment was decimated) while beating off the Greek assault.http://www.regioesercito.it/reparti/fanteria/rgt/rgt225.htm The ''Arezzo'' division was reformed and sent back to Albania, [[Korçë]], as part of the occupation force within [[Italian IV Corps]]. 5 April 1941 it took part in the [[Invasion of Yugoslavia]] as part of the [[Librazhd Sector]] under command of Italian 9th army.The Organization and Order of Battle of Militaries in World War II, By Charles D. Pettibone, p. 119 In this role, it captured parts of [[Montenegro]], and used as garrison in [[Zadar]], [[Ersekë]], [[Korçë]] and [[Pogradec]]. 29 January 1943, the division was reinforced by 343rd infantry regiment.http://www.regioesercito.it/reparti/fanteria/rgt/rgt343.htm The division remained in the area until the [[Armistice of Cassibile]] 8 September 1943. Following the Italian surrender to the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] in September 1943, the division was disarmed by the Germans. A large number of the men escaped to join the [[Yugoslav Partisans|partisans]]. ==Order of battle (1943)== *225.
